titlestmt.title: SSSC 10: Wisahketchahk and the Magic Headgear
titlestmt.author: Coming-Day

bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

body.head: Sacred Stories 10: Wisahketchahk and the Magic Headgear

p.seg: kîtahtawê wîsahkêcâhk êh-pmohtêt , kâ-wâpahtahk mîkiwâhp . Once upon a time, as Wisahketchahk was walking along, he saw a tipi.

êh-takohtêt ,
ham ham ! itwêw . When he reached it, he said, “Hum, hum!”
mâka mîna nôhtêhkatêw . As usual, he was hungry.
ahaw , tawâw ! itik . “Yes, yes, come in!” someone called to him.
êh-pîhtokêt , pêyakoyiwa nâpêwa . When he entered there was a lone man.
êh-nahapit , nanâtawâpahtam kêkway ka-mîcit . When he sat down, he looked all round for something to eat.
nama kêkway wâpahtam . He saw nothing.
êkosih apiw . So there he sat.

kîtahtawêh ômis itwêyiwa :
yâh , nistês onôhtêhkatâh ! itwêyiwa . Presently the other said, “Oh dear, but I am forgetting that my elder brother is hungry!” he said.
wêskwâhtêmihk êkotê kîkway êtokê êh-tahkopitêyik wâpahtam . He saw that something or other was tied fast in the doorway.

êwakoh itinamiyiwa , êh-âpahamiyit : pôt ôma astotn , sihkosiwayân ohci astotin , mîna kicohcikanis . The other took that thing and removed the covering: it turned out to be a headgear, a headgear of weasel-skin, and a little flute.
akwâsiwêpahamiyiwa iskotêw , êh-miyâhkasikêyit , miyâhkasamiyit astotin mina kicôhcikanis . The man scattered some embers of the fire and burned incense for the headgear and the flute.
ka-kitâpamêw , êh-tôtamiyit . He watched the man do it.
postastotinêyiwa , êh-yôhtênamiyit , êkwah wîpisisiyiw pêyak êh-otinamiyit . The man put on the headgear, opened the door-flap, and took one of his arrows.
êh-kitohtâyit , kiyipa pâpayiyiwa mostoswah pêyak , ôt êskwâhtêmih êh-pimipayiyit . When he blew on the flute, quickly a buffalo came running, and ran right past the doorway.
pimêyiwa ; nipahêyiwa . The man shot it and killed it.
kâwih kêtastotinêyiwa , êh-asiwatâyit , êh-tahkwaskwêpitamiyit apasôhk . He took off the headgear, put it back in its covering, and tied it fast to the wood of the tent-poles.
hâw , nistêsê , ntawi-manisah otêyaniy ; êwako pikoh ! itik . “Now, big brother, go cut out the tongue; only that!” he told him.
tâpwêh otinam , êh-nitawi-manisahk otêyaniy . So he took it, and went out and cut out the tongue. LB on {tâpwêh otinam}: Probably the word {môhkomân}: “knife” has dropped out in record.
mân êkâ nika-kîspohtân ! itêyihtam . “It looks as if we should not get our fill!” he thought.
êkwah nawacîw . Then he prepared the roast.

wayawîw ,
mistahi nk-ôtinên wiyâs , êh-itêyihtahk . He went out of the tent, thinking, “I shall take a lot of the meat.”
nama kêkway mostoswah ; sipwêhtêyiwa . The buffalo was not there; it had gone away.
kâwih pîhtokêw , êkwah êh-mîcisocik . He went back in, and they ate.
nisîm , kakikê ciw omah êkos êy-isi-minahoyin ? itêw . “Little brother, do you always kill game in this manner?” he asked him.

seg.gloss: I never tramp about when I want to kill game.

p.seg: êyakô oma nipostastotinân , wâh-minahoyâni , êh-kitohtâyân , êh-pêcimakik mostoswak , itwêyiwa . I put on this head-dress, when I want to kill game, and by blowing the flute, summon the buffalos,” said the man.
kah ! itêw . “You don't say!” he answered him.

ômis îtêyihtam wîsahkêcâhk :
nika-kimotamawâw ! itêyihtam ; Wisahketchahk thought thus: “I shall steal it from him!” he thought;
nik-âcimostawâw , ta-nôhtêhkwasit , êkâ ta-kiskêyihtahk , kimotamawaki , itêyihtam . “I shall tell him stories to make him sleepy, so that he will not know when I steal it from him.” he thought.
êkwah êh-tipiskâyik , âcimostawêw , ê-wîh-kakwê-nôhtêhkwastimât . Then, when night came, he told him tales, so as to make him get sleepy.
êh-kiskêyimât , êh-nôhtêhkwasiyit , êkwah kawisimôwak . When he knew that the other was sleepy, then they went to bed.
nama wîh-nipâw . He kept from going to sleep.

mayaw êh-nipâyit , otinam , êh-wayawîhtatât ôm âstotin , êh-kimotit , êh-nayahtahk . As soon as the other slept, he took the headgear, and went out of the tent with it, stealing it and carrying it over his shoulder.
êkos îsi tapasîw . In this way he fled.

pâh-pimipahtâw , kontah êh-wâ-wâkohtêt ,
êkâ ta-mitisit , êh-itêyimât . He ran on and on, making all kinds of turns and twists, with the thought, “So that he may not track me.”
êkwah ê-wîh-wâpaniyik , itah êh-wayahcâyik , êkotah kawisimôw . Then, towards dawn in a hollow place he lay down.
kîsikâki , pimohtêyâni , nika-wâpamik , pê-nawaswâsicih , itêyihtam ; “If I walk on in daytime, he will see me, in case he comes here pursuing me,” he thought;
iyikohk tipiskâki , nka-tapasîn , êh-itêyihtahk , êkotah kâ-kawisimot . “When night comes, I shall continue in my flight,” he thought, as he lay down.
mayaw êh-pimisihk , nipâw , mitonih êh-papêtikosihk , êh-nayôhtahk ôm astotn . As soon as he lay down, he fell asleep, lying all doubled up, with the headgear still on his shoulders.

kîtahtawê , êh-mêkwâ-nipât , koskoskonik ,
nistêsê , waniskâh ! kikipiskawin . Suddenly, in the midst of his sleep, someone shook him and roused him, saying to him, “Big brother, get up! You are blocking my way.
niwîh-kotawân , êh-itikot . I want to build the fire.”
ês ôma pîhcâyihk wîkiyihk , itah kâ-kotawêyit mâna êkotah ês ômah kâ-nipât . There he was, inside the other's tipi; he had been sleeping right were the other always built the fire.
waniskâw . He arose.

seg.gloss: “Dear me, little brother, I am afflicted with sleep-walking like this!

p.seg: awah êtokê kah-otinamân kiwîskwêhpitâkan ! itêw , êh-kêtôwatêt , kâwih êh-tahkopitahk . And here it seems I have taken your sacred bundle!” he told him, removing his burden and tying it back in its place. LB on {awah}: The animate form {awah}: “this” is a slip of record or speech, since the following verb has inanimate form of object.
ohcitaw nka-kimotin , itêyihtam . “All the more surely, I will steal it,” he thought.
asay mîna êh-tipiskâyik , âcimostawêw , ê-wîh-kakwê-nêstohkwastimât . That night again he told him stories to make him sleepy.
êyikoh mina êh-nipâyit , asay mîna otinam , êh-wîwahot , êh-tapasît . As soon as the other went to sleep, again he took it, slung it over his shoulder, and made off.
kapê-tipis pimipahtâw . All night long he ran.

miyâmay wâhyaw nitayân ! êh-itêyihtahk , ê-wîh-wâpaniyik , mistikwah êh-cimasoyit , ê-sakâyik ,
êkotah nka-nipân , itêyihtam . When he thought, “Surely, I am far off,” towards dawn, where a tree stood, in a wooded place, “Here I shall sleep.” he thought.
êkosi nahapiw , mistikohk êh-aspatisihk . So he sat down, leaning against the tree.
ômis îsi kîskipitam oskotâkay , mistikwah ôhi êh-asitahpitisot . Like this he tore his jacket and tied himself fast to the tree.
êkos îsi êh-nipât . In this position he went to sleep.
aspin pikoh êh-nipât , kîtahtawê kâ-koskoskonikot . Hardly had he gone off to sleep, when suddenly the other shook him awake.

seg.gloss: You are delaying me; my headgear!

p.seg: niwîh-kakwê-minahoh ! itik . I want to try and kill some game!” the other was saying to him.
êh-tôhkâpit , awîn ôma , pîhcâyihk kîh-apiw , apasôhk êh-astahpisot . When he opened his eyes, what was this? He was sitting inside the place, tied fast to a tent-pole.

ômis îtwêw :
yahô ! He said, “Dear me!

êkos ôma mâna êh-isi-kîskwêhwasiskiyân , pikw êtokê êh-otinamân kiwîskwêhpitâkan , nisîm ! itêw , êh-pasikôt , kâwih êh-tahkopitahk . this is the way I am afflicted with the habit of walking in my sleep; and it seems that in some way I have taken up your sacred bundle, little brother!” he said to him, and rose to his feet, and tied the thing back where it belonged.
kiyipah otinamiyiwa , êh-kwayakonamiyit , ê-postastotinêyit . The other at once took it, shook it out, and put on the headgear.
âsay mîna êh-kitohtâyit , pêcimêyiwa mostoswah . Again when he blew the flute, he called a buffalo.
mîn êyakoni pimwêyiwa , êh-nipahâyit . This one, too, he shot and killed.
hâ , nisîm , tânêhkih pêyak pikoh kâh-nipahat ? itêw . “Now, little brother, why do you kill only one?” he asked him.
hâ , êkoyikohk ka-kîsponânaw pêyak otêyaniy , itêw . “Oh, one tongue is quite enough to give us our fill,” he told him.
êkosi tahkopitamiyiwah mîna ôma otastotiniyiw . With this he again tied up that headgear of his.
êkwa wiya ntawih-otinam otêyiniy . And Wisahketchahk went and took up the tongue.
êkos ê-kîh-mîcisocik , piyisk mîna tipiskâyiw . When thus they had eaten, finally night came again.
iyikoh mîna êh-nipâyit , âsay mîna kimotiw , âsay mîna êh-tapasît . Again, as soon as the other slept, he stole it, and again made off in flight.
miton êkwah wîh-kakwê-mîhkawikiw . He was bound to run fast, now, and far.
wâhyaw mîn êh-ayât , âsay mîna ê-wîh-wâpaniyik , âsay mîna sêskisiw . When again he had gone a great distance, and again dawn was near, again he went into the brush.

nîso mistikwah êh-nîswaskisoyit , êkota tastawâyihk nahapiw , êh-asitahpitisot ,
namoya êkwah êkotê pîhcâyihk nka-nipân ! êh-itêyihtahk . Where two trees stood side by side, there he sat down between them, and tied himself fast, thinking, “This time I shall not be sleeping inside there!”
êkos îsi nipâw . So he went to sleep.
kîtahtawêh êh-mêkwâ-nipât , kâ-koskoskonikot . Suddenly, in the midst of his sleep, there was the other, shaking him awake.

seg.gloss: I want to put wood on the fire.”

p.seg: ês ôma itah k-ôh-wayawîhk , iskwâhtêmihk êkotah ês ôma k-âsitahpisot . It appeared that in the place where one went out of the tent, right in the doorway it appeared that he was tied fast.

seg.gloss: “Dear me, little brother, I told you I was given to walking in my sleep.

p.seg:
nama ciy awa kitastotin êwako ,
nik-âyâwik ! êh-itêyimit kitastotin ? itêw . Are you sure that this headgear of yours has not been thinking ‘Let him possess me!’ meaning me?” he asked him.

mîna êh-tipiskâyik , âsay mîna êh-nipâyit , otinam , êh-wîwahot , mîna êh-tapasît , êh-sôhkih êh-tapasît . The next night, as soon as the other slept, again he took the thing slung the bundle across his shoulder, and again made off, fleeing with all his might. CHECK êh-sôhkih. HCW: fragment
iyikoh mîna êy-wîh-wâpahk , âsay mîna wîh-nipâw . When dawn again was near, again he meant to sleep.
kîhcêhkosîw ispimihk . He climbed high up on a tree.
êkotah êkwah nipâw , mîna êh-asitahpisot . There he went to sleep, after again tying himself fast.

aspin ê-nipât , kîtahtawê mistik ohci kâ-koskoskoyahkahokot ,
waniskâh , nistêsê ! ka-kaskâpason ! niwîn-pônên , êh-itikot , He had gone off to sleep, when suddenly the other was prodding him awake with a stick, saying to him, “Get up, big brother! You will be strangled by smoke! I am going to put wood on the fire,”
wîkiyihk ispimih êh-akosît , itah k-ôh-wayawiyâpahtêyik êkota . and there he was, perched on top of the other's dwelling, right at the place where the smoke comes out of the tipi.

yahô , nisîm , êkoyikohk êkos ôma êsih-kiskwêhkwasiskiyân ! itêw , êh-pêh-nîhtakosît , êh-pîhtokêt , êh-ta-tahkopitahk , itah kâh-kîh-tahkopitêyik . “Dear me, little brother, just see how terribly I am afflicted with sleep-walking!” he said to him, as he climbed down and came into the tent and tied the thing back into the place where it had been tied fast.

ômis îtik :
wîsahkêcâhk , namoya ka-kîh-kimotamawin nitastotin . The other answered him thus: “Wisahketchahk, you will not be able to steal my headgear from me.

seg.gloss: It was this headgear itself which brought you back here whenever you went to sleep.

p.seg: nawac ta-pônihtâyan ! itik . You might as well give it up!” the other told him.
êkos ê-kîh-mîcisot , sipwêhtêw . At this, as soon as he had eaten, he went away.
êkoyikohk êskwâk âtayôhkêwin . That is the end of the sacred story.
